section: Dhanasari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: First of all, the lotuses bloomed in the woods;

melody.description: Dhanasari is a sense of being completely carefree. This sensation arises from a feeling of contentment and ‘richness’ from the things we have in our lives and gives the listener a positive and optimistic attitude towards the future.

author.author: Saint Namdev
author.description:
Saint Namdev [1270 - 1350] was born in the state of Maharashtra village of Naras-Vamani, in Satara district (presently called Narsi Namdev). His father was called Damshet, a tailor, and his mother was called Gonabai.

The main spiritual message of Saint Namdev, just like the Sikh Gurus, was to emphasise the importance of living a married householder life and that through marriage, living in the world and meditating on God, one could attain enlightenment. Sixty-one of his hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. He was also a close friend of Saint Trilochan.

section: Dhanasari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: from them, all the swan-souls came into being.

melody.description: Dhanasari is a sense of being completely carefree. This sensation arises from a feeling of contentment and ‘richness’ from the things we have in our lives and gives the listener a positive and optimistic attitude towards the future.

author.author: Saint Namdev

text: ਕ੍ਰਿਸ੍ਨਾ ਤੇ ਜਾਨਊ ਹਰਿ ਹਰਿ ਨਾਚੰਤੀ ਨਾਚਨਾ ॥੧॥
section: Dhanasari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Know that, through Krishna, the Lord, Har, Har, the dance of creation dances. ||1||

transliteration.text: krisnā tē jānaū har har nāchantī nāchanā .1.

melody.description: Dhanasari is a sense of being completely carefree. This sensation arises from a feeling of contentment and ‘richness’ from the things we have in our lives and gives the listener a positive and optimistic attitude towards the future.

section: Dhanasari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: First of all, there was only the Primal Being.

section: Dhanasari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: From that Primal Being, Maya was produced.

text: ਹਰਿ ਕਾ ਬਾਗਰਾ ਨਾਚੈ ਪਿੰਧੀ ਮਹਿ ਸਾਗਰਾ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥
section: Dhanasari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: In this Garden of the Lord, we all dance, like water in the pots of the Persian wheel. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: har kā bāgarā nāchai pindhī mah sāgarā .1. rahāu .

translation.text: There is no other than the Lord.

text: ਕੇਸਵਾ ਬਚਉਨੀ ਅਈਏ ਮਈਏ ਏਕ ਆਨ ਜੀਉ ॥੨॥
section: Dhanasari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: The Lord says, "This creation and I are one and the same."||2||

transliteration.text: kēsavā bachaunī aīē maīē ēk ān jīu .2.

melody.description: Dhanasari is a sense of being completely carefree. This sensation arises from a feeling of contentment and ‘richness’ from the things we have in our lives and gives the listener a positive and optimistic attitude towards the future.

section: Dhanasari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Like the pots on the Persian wheel, sometimes the world is high, and sometimes it is low.

text: ਭ੍ਰਮਿ ਭ੍ਰਮਿ ਆਏ ਤੁਮ ਚੇ ਦੁਆਰਾ ॥
section: Dhanasari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Wandering and roaming around, I have come at last to Your Door.

transliteration.text: bhram bhram āē tum chē duārā .

melody.description: Dhanasari is a sense of being completely carefree. This sensation arises from a feeling of contentment and ‘richness’ from the things we have in our lives and gives the listener a positive and optimistic attitude towards the future.

section: Dhanasari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: O Lord, please save me from Maya, the cause of death. ||3||4||

melody.description: Dhanasari is a sense of being completely carefree. This sensation arises from a feeling of contentment and ‘richness’ from the things we have in our lives and gives the listener a positive and optimistic attitude towards the future.
